title: How to Perform a Hamstring Curl

steps.title: Lie on the floor.
steps.content: Lie on the floor. To do a hamstring curl on the floor, lie on your stomach with your hands in front of you, slightly wider than your shoulders.

steps.title: Lift your feet.
steps.content: Lift your feet. From this position, lift one or both feet off the floor by bending your knees. When doing this, you should be keeping your knees on the floor. Keep your back straight and your knees close together throughout the repetition. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Straighten your legs.
steps.content: Straighten your legs. Release your hamstring by lowering your feet back to the floor. From here, repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions, about 12-15 if you're a beginner. [2] X Expert Source Danny Gordon Certified Fitness Coach Expert Interview. 18 October 2019.

steps.title: Add weight.
steps.content: Add weight. If these are too easy and you don’t notice the contraction in your hamstrings, add some weight. You can do this by either wrapping ankle weights around your lower legs, or by holding a dumbbell between your feet as you lift them off the ground.

steps.title: Find the machine.
steps.content: Find the machine. The hamstring curl machine will have stacked weights on one side, a flat bench for your body, and a padded cylinder for you to move with your legs.

steps.title: Adjust the lever.
steps.content: Adjust the lever. Laying on your stomach, the padded cylinder behind you should go on top of your legs. The pad should hit just a few inches below your calf muscles. You can adjust it using the lever until it is in the right spot for your height. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Keep your torso flat.
steps.content: Keep your torso flat. Tighten your core muscles to help you keep your torso flat on the bench. Ensure your legs are fully stretched in the starting position, and grab the handles in front of your shoulders to steady yourself.

steps.title: Exhale and curl.
steps.content: Exhale and curl. As you breathe out, curl your legs up as far as possible without lifting your upper legs off of the bench. Hold for a second once you reach the fully contracted position. [4] X Research source If it is too easy or too hard, you can stop and adjust the weight using the stack next to you.

steps.title: Inhale and release.
steps.content: Inhale and release. As you breathe in, bring your legs slowly back down to your starting position. [5] X Research source Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions, or 12-15 if you're a beginner. [6] X Expert Source Danny Gordon Certified Fitness Coach Expert Interview. 18 October 2019.

steps.title: Find a swiss ball.
steps.content: Find a swiss ball. Those are the oversized, light, rubber balls often used for Pilates. It doesn’t matter which size you use. Choose one that you’re comfortable with. You’ll get a bigger contraction with a larger ball.

steps.title: Lay on the floor.
steps.content: Lay on the floor. With your back on the floor, roll the ball up under your feet. You want your feet to be on the top center of the ball. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Lift your hips.
steps.content: Lift your hips. Put your full weight between your feet (on the ball) and your shoulder blades. Use your arms to stabilize yourself. This will be your starting position.

steps.title: Bring the ball towards you.
steps.content: Bring the ball towards you. Bend your knees, pulling the ball as close as you can to your bottom. This will contract the hamstring. Hold for a brief pause and then push the ball back out to your starting position. [8] X Research source Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions. Do about 12-15 reps when you're just getting started with hamstring curls. [9] X Expert Source Danny Gordon Certified Fitness Coach Expert Interview. 18 October 2019.
